locations.name: NYU_ITP
text: After taking a 7 month break from dating, I was nervous about getting back at it but thought it was time for me to meet someone new. I matched with a data scientist on Coffee Meets Bagel. We had fun chatting online and he asked me out at the end of our conversation. Our first date was on a Tuesday night at a wine bar in flatiron. To match with my style, he showed up with a choker. It was hysterical. The tension was gone and the rest of the date went exceptionally well.

I wanted to hang out with him again but couldn’t squeeze time out of my busy school schedule so I invited him to go to Ambient Church with me on that Saturday with two of my classmates. As someone who hung out primarily in Manhattan and knew very little about art, he still came all the way to deep Bushwick just to spend time with me. We had another fun night together. Afterwards, we went out for dinner and drinks every week the next four weeks. He once canceled our Brooklyn Botanical Garden plan last minute because he told me he was in bad mood for the week and wanted time for himself. I didn’t question his intention. It seemed like he was just really having a tough week. On our fifth date, I invited him to a two-day group show at my grad school ITP which I will be showing projects I had been working hard on the past four months. He said he will come to the second show because he also wanted to go to our after party. The project I was showing was situated at a dark corner next to our blue bin shelf in our shop at the end of our floor. It was a modern take on tarot card reading where my collaborator and I took turns to hide behind our installation to initiate the magic.

An hour before the end of the second show, I was sitting behind the curtains, alone, when I received his text, 'Hey, I was out with my colleagues last night and was hungover the whole day. Won’t be able to make it to your show. Sorry'. Before I was able to process it, the show got flooded with last minute visitors, followed by chaotic post-show clean up and after party at Better Days in the Lower East Side. I drank a lot of prosecco and told one of my classmates about the upsetting text. He told me I should speak up for myself and gave me some cocaine. I took some, drank more prosecco and danced. On my car ride home, it was the first time in 24 hour when everything was finally calm and quiet. Tears fell down my cheek. I texted him the next day that I was disappointed about his behavior.

He responded, ‘I am sorry. I know it is really important to you but I was feeling incredibly ill. That said, I have to be honest though, I was also a little anxious about going. Anxious because I’ve been feeling extremely confused about what I want in life and relationships. I am not in a state at all to engage myself in anything long term/serious, nor do I think I really want to. Making plans to view your work in school kinda made me feel like the initial stages of my previous relationship. It threw me off. I figured I want to be honest with you, not to lead you on.’

locations.name: Broken_Land
text: I think he lived in Manhattan, which felt so mystifying to me. He took the East River Ferry over to Brooklyn. I know this because he texted a picture with, “Beautiful sunset from the East River Ferry. Be there soon!!!!” and made me momentarily second guess leaving my house. I showed up at my favorite neighborhood bar looking forward to my preferred first date incentive: a homemade pina colada on the back porch. That’s when I saw it. This guy was standing in the middle of my neighborhood bar, on a Segway. When I walked up to him, he towered over me on it. He looked down at me and we shook hands. And to my horror, he rode it out to the back porch, trying to match my walking pace. Seeing my face, he admitted that his friends recommended he not show up on a first date on a Segway. I disagreed. “Actually,” I said, “I think it’s a great idea.” I envisioned a woman rolling up to the date on her own Segway and the two of them collapsing in fits of laughter, relieved that, finally, they had both found the one. The pair, gliding off into their promising future, perfecting their Segway’s pace so that they can still hold hands. I was jolted back to reality as I watched him methodically collapse it, attracting a few looks. I liked his self-assurance, though! This guy clearly knew who he was and what he liked. I really wanted to give him a shot. But his story dominated mine. He spent the duration of the drink talking about the all the property he owned. He cut off my sentences like he cut off foot traffic inside the bar, steering the conversation in whatever direction the urge took him. As I looked at my watch, he asked, before I left, did I want to ride it? I paused. I never wanted to see this human-who-cuts-women-off again. But, I wasn’t certain that I’d get another chance to ride a Segway. And so I did, in the nearby parking lot. In public. It was just alright. And then I got the hell out of there. I immediately called my best friend, Nancy, and explained to her what had happened in a breathless run on sentence. Just as she was getting the gist, I heard “Heyyy!”. I froze. There he was, rolling right on by, calling out to me on my street, the sidewalk cafe-goers barely looking up from their pints.

locations.name: Cafe_Grumpy
text: I met him on Bumble. This is when I was almost… I am ready to give up on the apps. I don’t want this. I really don’t have time for this. I am tired. And then, I matched with someone and I said 'Wow, he’s gorgeous! This is incredible' and also he is a little weird to talk to but it’s fine. I’ve always been asked out for a drink and this was the first time I was asked out for coffee and I thought 'Aww. That would be so sweet. That’s really nice to me'. So I went and had coffee with him which actually turned out to be lunch and then three coffees because we spent like five or six hours walking around Midtown just talking and it was nice.

Every date I’ve been, it follows the same protocol: You meet for an hour or two. After that, you wait for two to three days before you text. And then, if you have to meet, you meet once or twice a week. This person messaged me the next morning saying it was so great and he wanted to see me as soon as possible so that was like in two days time. We met for drinks and we got ice cream. Basically, it was nice except that we were meeting every other day. It’s going really well. I’m from India. He’s from India except that he left home 18 years back so he’s not as in tune. He really likes that about me that I would talk about home a lot. When you’re living in the city and you see all these diverse cultures but then there’s this one culture that just brings you back home so it made him feel happy.

It’s been about three weeks and then the weird stuff started which is that when he started getting drunk, he would talk to me about how he’s gonna fight for this and he’s gonna make it work. He really wants this and it’s something real for him. I would just be like...okay. I mean sure.

I had to go back to India for two weeks. A week before that, when he was super drunk, he said, 'You can tell your family about me. I’ve told my mom about you'. I thought about it and said 'Oh well, fine'. I mean at the end of the day, this is nice. He was a lot older. He was 10 years older than me which is why I’m like, if not now then when, for you? Cool. I’m not gonna say anything. I’ll see when I have to but it’s going fine. I’m okay with it. It’s just a little strange.
